description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen the livelihoods and safety of communities particularly women and youth affected by inter-ethnic conflict in Amhara region, North Shewa zone of Ethiopia.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1.1 Gender sensitive peace mapping assessment report produced & refreshed during implementation 2. Number of Community peace committees established, and dialogue and reconciliation forums organized. 3. Number of people with enhanced knowledge and skills in peace initiatives that emerge from the peace committees disaggregated by sex 4. Number of action plans developed by the peace committees 5. Number of local government leaders and technical experts with increased knowledge and skills in peace building and reconciliation 6. # of women leaders/law makers trained on conflict prevention, management and peace building 7. # of vulnerable people who become aware and received access to judicial and legal aid/support
Output 1.2 1. Number of Key stakeholders, gate keepers, CBOs and influential community leaders are identified through mapping 2. Number of Area based plans of action developed in each of the target Woredas) and town administrations 3. # of computers and printers supplied to target Woreda Sector offices 4. # of People drawn from local institutions and community leaders and trained on justice, human rights, peace building and conflict management 5. # of Zonal High Court, Woreda First Instance Courts, and Police Offices that are supported/capacitated through accessing materials to facilitate access to justice
Output 1.3 1. Number of People with enhanced awareness on CEWARN 2. Number of traditional conflict resolution mechanisms reconstituted 3. Number of Peace committee established at Woreda level, constituting elders, women, youth, ethnic group leaders and supported to develop bylaws recognized by the government 4. Number of Platform that brings government and local community representatives from both ethnicities? established 5. Number of Experts and government officials with enhanced knowledge and skills in DS methodologies and become capable to develop their respective woreda plan 6. Number of target Woredas developed plan by

comment.narrative: Output 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.1,2.2, 2.3, 3.1, 3.2 , 3.3 TBBD during assessment but most of them are zero at current state Output 4.1 None-of the sector offices in the target Woredas do have the minimum capacity to operate and provide service to the public

Output 1.1 1. Mapping assessment report 2. 50 committees, 5 peace conferences, 50 dialogues & reconciliation forums. (Women 40%, Youth 30%) 3. 100 people 4. 36 action plan in all target Woredas 5. 500 people (260 women & 240 youth) trained in 4 rounds 6. 50 lawyers (from target Woredas and Zones) 7. 2000 people (at least 70% women) received legal assistance
Output 1.2 1. Mapping exercise 2. 9 Area based plans prepared 3. 35 computers supplied to Woredas (2 town administrations) 4. 250 people (40% female) trained for five days 5. Seven (Two zonal and 5 Woreda court and police offices) capacited
Output 1.3 1. 100 people (community and government) 2. 200 people (50% female) 3. 5 peace committees (1 per target Woreda) 4. High-level platform established & 5 meetings held 5. 150 people (50% female) trained in durable solution 6. 30 experts trained in 5 target Woredas
Output 2.1 1. Assessment conducted 2. 200 businesses got restored sheds and training 3. 750 MSMEs (women and youth owned) 4. 500 MSMEs (women and youth owned) 5. 500 businesses
Output 2.2 1. 5 plans in 5 Woredas 2. 1 by-law 3. 10 infrastructures and facilities rehabilitated 4. 150 damaged properties (70% women owned) rehabilitated
Output 3.1 1. Rapid gender assessment conducted and one stop centers established in 5 Woredas 2. 150 trained in SGBV and gender equality 3. Legal aid services functional in 5 Woredas and at least 60% of women access the service 4. MHPSS support provided to 70% of the vulnerable groups, with 50% satisfaction in the MHPSS support provided
Output 3.2 1. 1 assessment on livelihood opportunities 2. 3000 vulnerable people (60% female) 3. 1500 vulnerable women IDPs 4. 100 VSLAs 5. 500 Youth (70% female) 6. 750 farmers (70% female) 7. 1000 youth (60% female) 8. 60% express satisfaction in the quality of livelihoods training support provided
Output 3.3 1. 100 members of police 2. 9 (one in each Woreda) police units established 3. 50% of women and youth enabled to access justice through enhanced legal aid centers 4. 50% of justice officials trained 5. 500 victims of SGBV receiving training on HR 6. 200 paralegal from justice sector trained 7. 200 women got legal aid 8. Legal awareness capacity building 50% female and 50% youth attend the training 9. One safe house established
Output 4.1 1. 4 monitoring visits by sector bureaus 2. 24 monitoring visits 3. Seven sectors in Nine Woredas are supported with materials (furniture and others) 4. Nine offices refurbished
